comments.commentBody:
Yes, fetal monitors mean more c-sections. However, they also mean fewer babies born dead or with brain injuries. By the time a stethoscope can pick up fetal distress, most of the time damage has already been done. Some of the c-sections done for fetal distress are unnecessary, some of those babies would have been born safely. But wouldn't you happily accept a routine surgical procedure to spare your child the risk of brain damage or death?

Epidurals do not increase c-sections. The clearest evidence is this: During the 1990s, many hospitals increased their epidural rates dramatically in a single year as the procedure became more available. No detectable change in c-section rates.

No, it's not about greed and convenience. It's about risk aversion. Decades ago, babies were born dead or birth-injured significantly more often. And if we're doing 10 c-sections to save one baby, so what? It's cheap at the price.
Do you mean to stand there and tell me that the "regular season" and its talking heads EVER ends?  Color me dubious.......

Perhaps the worst effect of the NFL draft is the way it has monopolized sports media, including most sports talk shows, for the past several weeks. The only thing we don't know about every NFL prospective player is whether he squeezes toothpaste from the middle of the tube, or from the end. Let me know when the regular season starts.
Condescension inappropriately drips from your comment ... .
Well, when I was very young I once watched paint dry.  It was more interesting than the NFL Draft........
Why would anyone watch the draft? I feel sorry for those with nothing better to do.

P.T. Barnum's maxim again proves correct:
"There's a sucker born every minute."
And the suckers are the fans of this idiocity.
This is what America is all about. Little more.
The Draft is just NFL's attempt to compete with reality TV

Hi Jerry M., You neglect to mention that Sulzberger, Sr., published the Pentagon Papers, a brave act, in support of freedom of the press, in DEFIANCE of USG. Obama, beyond an effective White House machine for managing news, has shown greater contempt for government transparency than any previous POTUS. Espionage Act prosecutions, more than all presidents combined. His DOJ setting dangerous precedents in disrespect for habeas corpus rights (detainees) and Obama personally approving indefinite detention.

You sully A.O.S.'s journalistic courage through omitting that chapter, and by implication, giving Obama a free pass in his efforts to undermine a free press. Sorry, but I think of Snowden as an American patriot exposing the corruption, illegality, and murderous intent (for what else are drone killings?) of Obama and his administration. We of course differ, but I await your and the many posters' response to Obama's civil liberties record, of which freedom of the press is among the most important.

Of course you are on safe ground. Most Times readers haven't the vaguest idea who A.O.S. was--I only wish the present editorial board would take seriously his legacy and refrain from the demonization of Putin. News coverage, yes; but not losing sight of the initial coup and the move to place NATO on the border. Days ago, 40 unarmed protester were burned to death in Odessa by fascist thugs. Where the outcry, from NYT or its posters?

Nicholas, all excellent suggestions, and I might add sending emails to the White House to encourage as strong a response as possible to both rescue as many of the girls as possible and to orchestrate a fatal blow to Boko Haram itself. This might mean aiding a corrupt Nigerian government in the short term. But aid can be targeted so it really helps the people of Nigeria, in spite of their government. If done well, we could increase the chances that the Nigerian people will fix their corrupt government in their own time. The important thing is to support the Nigerian people and the aspirations of their children, which is their real future.

What justifies the "castle defense" is fearing for one's life or the life of another person. Someone who leaves the garage door open, having been burgled twice, doesn't seem particularly fearful. Likely that's because they are in no danger if they just don't go into the garage when they hear someone there, but instead turn on the light, call the police, shout through the door, whatever.

these warnings already exist in Europe and have for decades, you are also warned about carjackings, pickpockets, tuberculosis, AIDS, shark attacks and various other things that will almost never affect anyone traveling to the United States, when I lived in Northern Europe I used to think that all these warnings about the United States were intentional and meant to prevent Europeans form traveling (and spending their money) outside of Europe...

There is a growing list of states I will avoid because of their gun laws.  Europeans and others visiting the US should be warned by their foreign ministries to be aware of the trigger happy nature of the culture in many parts of the US, much as we are warned about tropical diseases and terrorists.

This unfortunate young man was not killed because of cultural differences in terms of the right to privacy in your own home.  Implying that in Europe, if something doesn’t have a fence around it or the door is open, then somehow you can just walk up and check things out, is simply not true and I am sure that this 17 year old intruder and would be burglar was perfectly aware of this.  In several of the Scandinavian countries, there are laws which loosely translate into “freedom to roam,” basically giving the general public legal right to use all land (private or public) for recreation or exercise.  However, having lived in these countries for many years, I can ensure you that this does not in anyway whatsoever extend into the privacy of people’s homes or their garages and citizenry has the right to self defense, to protect private property from robbery, trespassing, assault, rape and so on, further you are allowed to use force that is not excessive.  In short, more or less the same as in the United States.  So, obviously, the question is, what constitutes excessive force?  In this case the home owner was on the edge, had been having problems with burglaries in the past, he had a wife and a ten month old baby in the house.  I don’t think this is straight forward and it needs to be tried in front of a jury and for us to judge without knowing more of the circumstances is not right.

The combination of castle doctrine, American culture and insanely easy access to guns make tragedies such as this inevitable.  An even greater tragedy is that this is just another death by gun shot in gun crazy America that will be repeated ad nauseum while American political gridlock and the deep pockets  of lobbyists prevents any meaningful reform. I love Americans but prefer to meet them on this side on the 49th.

Just as George Zimmerman should never have followed Trayvon Martin,  Mr. Kaarma should never have pointed a loaded shotgun into an unlit garage, least of all pulled the trigger 4 times to shoot into the dark.  If there is one hard and fast rule about using guns, even when legal, it's know what you're shooting at.  If you can't identify the target, don't shoot.  Mr. Kaarma never even made an attempt to discern who or what was in his garage.  It might have been the neighbor's cat or a wild animal.  Regardless, he didn't know and it was his responsibility to know.   There is no justification whatsoever for shooting blindly.  Like Mr. Zimmerman, Mr, Kaarma could have walked away. He could have taken shelter in his home, behind a door and waited for the intruder to leave.  There was no reason to fire except that he believed that he could act indiscriminately because he was defending his castle and he could assert his life or the lives of his family were in danger.  Mr. Kaarma made no effort to get out of the way when he all too easily could have gone another direction while still protecting his family.  I agree with the right to self-defense but not to right to fire into the dark at an unknown target.  There was no threat.  Petty theft or entering a garage without permission or knowledge of the owner should not mean the death penalty.  This was murder of convenience under the cover of a deeply flawed law.

Wow. Just wow. City slickers and 'good' country people? Based on what?!

Mr. Kaarma has every right to self-defense. But he was not defending himself. He and his family were in absolutely no danger. Burglary is not a violent crime and murder is not an appropriate response. Turning on the light, assessing the situation gun in hand, and demanding the trespassers gets off his property would have been reasonable. The kid would have no doubt been terrified. Mr. Kaarma could have decided to send him or have his wife called the police and let them do their job. And hey - if the kid charged at him he could have always fired off a bullet then. Firing into a dark room is plain stupid. Worse yet, the statements from the hairstylist could even be used to make the case for premeditation. He wanted to shoot someone, anyone. I do not believe Mr. Kaarma shot because he was afraid for himself. I think he felt a false sense of empowerment because of the gun in his hand and a twisted spirit of vigilantism that is somehow tolerated amongst some 'good' country people. This is not justice.

The police station being further away is not an excuse for breaking the law. Two wrongs don't make a right. I don't see how being willing to murder a human being for trespassing makes you a good person. I may just be a city dweller, but I do not see how you can excuse this man's actions.
As a teen, I was shot at while pulling a high school prank at someone's home.  As an adult, I would shoot someone prowling in my garage.

The home had been broken into two times but left his garage door open and when somebody went into the garage he fires into the dark four times with a shotgun.  It sounds more like he was setting a trap considering the previous burglaries, open garage door and motion detectors.   Also, the kids weren't trying to get into his house proper.

" I also can't blame a boy raised in Europe for not understanding Montana culture."

Are you seriously suggesting that in Europe trespassing and theft are accepted culture?

jms175 - that is what I as a liberal gun owner (not a gun nut, haven't fired them in 10 years) fear will be the result of the NRA, and what sure seems like a small percent of the population, are doing by their huge support for more guns everywhere.  And politicians who have to kowtow to them.
Just because a door is open no one has the right to enter it.

It sounds like the shooter may have set up the scene (open garage door, purse) to attract the previous burglar, with an intent to kill. If that's really what happened, a castle defense won't save him.

You may think the $10 bill scenario is just a piece of theoretical irony, but astonishingly, another commenter in this very section defends his/her right to shoot someone dead in much the same situation.
"No questions asked" - If we don't ask questions we'll have no idea what really happened.

No, the physical boundaries of one home are not sacrosanct--not in American law at least, and not in any mainstream religion.  Life, in contrast, is sacrosanct in almost all.  Taking a life to protect one's own life is justified as being the lesser of two evils. Taking a life to protect one's property when one's life is not in danger isn't justifed. It's the greater of two evils. We have a legal system to decide the punishment for those who commit crimes against property.  If, as you suggest, were to do the same thing, you, like Mr. Kaarma, would be committing an evil act not accepted by any civilized society,and, like him,  would be a murderer.

A hunter verifies before firing that the movement in the bushes is game, not a human. A man with that much fear,which you argue absolves him of guilt, should not be wielding a loaded weapon. Deadly force without clear-headed thinking is unjustifiable.
